title: WhatsApp's latest feature is an encrypted Snapchat Stories clone called 'Status'
text:

WhatsApp is taking on selfie-sharing app Snapchat with a brand new feature allowing users to post self-deleting pictures. 
Called WhatsApp Status, it will also allow users to post videos or GIFs that disappear after 24 hours. Just like regular WhatsApp messages , the new Status posts are encrypted end-to-end, meaning outsiders can't pry into what you're posting. 
Status updates can be sent to contacts through messages and adorned with annotations, stickers and emojis. 
According to TechCrunch, the feature was rolled out to beta testers last November and is now making its way to users on iOS, Windows Phone and Android. Read More WhatsApp launches Status, an encrypted Snapchat Stories clone (Photo: WhatsApp) 
WhatsApp has had an option for users to post a status since it launched eight years ago. 
“The original idea behind the project was to build an application that lets your friends and other contacts know what you’re up to,” CEO Jan Koum told TechCrunch . 
This kind of update isn't surprising as Facebook, which owns WhatsApp, has long had its eye on Snapchat's own set of features. It introduced a similar feature for Instagram last August . 
The scale of WhatsApp, which has over 1.2 billion monthly users, could deal a blow to Snapchat which is currently planning to go public. Read More Facebook launches 'Recommendations' to help people get advice from their nearest and dearest Here's what WhatsApp's status used to look like (Photo: WhatsApp) 
It expects to raise up to $3 billion in the offering, anticipated sometime this spring. The IPO will reportedly value Snap (Snapchat's parent company) at upwards of $25 billion. It's one of the most eagerly awaited public offerings of the year.
